Award.AwardTitle: MIT PRIMES: Program for Research In Mathematics, Engineering, and Science for High School Students
Award.AbstractNarration:
MIT PRIMES is a free, year-long research program for high school students. This proposal requests funding for research projects on representations of symplectic reflection algebras in positive characteristic, representations of continuous Hecke algebras in positive characteristic, the structure of lower central series of associative algebras defined by generators and relations, the structure of ideals generated by terms of the lower central series defined by generators and relations, thracklability of graphs, decay of crossing numbers, Ramsey multiplicity, the visibility conjecture, the Richter-Thomassen conjecture, and coinvariants of incompressible vector fields.

PRIMES students will work on their projects during the academic year, aided by weekly meetings with their mentors (MIT Mathematics Department graduate students) on the MIT campus. The projects will be presented at annual PRIMES conferences, and final papers will be posted on the Program website and disseminated through arXiv.org and academic journals. Participation in PRIMES would help talented high school students discover the beauty of mathematical research and would inspire them to choose careers in the mathematical sciences. A special section of PRIMES, called PRIMES Circle, will be dedicated to serving students from urban high schools. PRIMES Circle students would learn an advanced mathematical topic in a challenging academic environment through directed reading and problem-solving. This would serve as preparation for further research and encouragement for pursuing degrees in the mathematical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PRIMES is a free, year-long after-school research and enrichment program for high school students, based at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It includes three main sections: MIT PRIMES offers research projects and guided reading to students from Greater Boston; PRIMES-USA is a national math research program for high school juniors; and PRIMES Circle is a math enrichment section for urban public high school students from the Boston area. In 2013-2015, more than 180 students have done research and participated in enrichment activities in mathematics, computer science, and computational biology under the aegis of the PRIMES program. They presented their projects at annual conferences at MIT and produced 50 research papers, nine of which have already been published in academic journals.

PRIMES has developed an innovative approach, based on the combination of learning and research, which allows high school students to learn advanced areas of math and science and to participate in cutting-edge research in a short period of time. Projects are formulated by university faculty and mentored by graduate students and postdoctoral scholars. PRIMES has developed a set of guidelines for formulating successful mathematical projects for high school research:

1. Accessible beginning. The initial steps must be simple to get started.

2. Flexibility. It is useful to think about several related questions, switching from one to another if stuck, and to tweak the questions if they are too hard or insufficiently interesting.

3. Computer (experimental) component. A possibility of computer-assisted exploration aimed at finding patterns and making conjectures is very useful. In this case, students, who often have strong programming skills, can contribute to the project early, even when they don’t yet have a working knowledge of the theoretical tools. It is also easier to learn new mathematical concepts, e.g., those from algebra and representation theory, through a hands-on experience with a computer algebra system.

4. Adviser involvement. It is important to have an opportunity to consult with a research mathematician other than the mentor – usually the professor or researcher who suggested the project.

5. Big picture/motivation. It is important to connect, at least at the level of ideas, to a wider context and to other people’s work.

6. Learning component. The project should encourage the student to study advanced mathematics on a regular basis.

7. Doability. It should be reasonable to expect that a good student would obtain some new results within several months and produce publishable results in one year.

8. Relation to the mentor’s research program or area.

The results of PRIMES research have been widely disseminated at conferences, posted online for free access, and submitted to academic journals for publication.

PRIMES has explored various formats of research and enrichments activities, such as individual and group research projects, directed reading group, distance mentoring over telecommunication channels, studying advanced topics in a game-like setting, writing of research and expository papers, and conference presentations. The five-year experience of running the PRIMES program has been summed up in an article by PI Pavel Etingof and two members of PRIMES staff, Slava Gerovitch and Tanya Khovanova, “Mathematical Research in High School: The PRIMES Experience,” published in  The Notices of the AMS 62 (2015). PRIMES has established partnerships with a number of other universities. The dissemination of the PRIMES experience should encourage creation of similar programs at other academic institutions.
